Various bus services get you to Castle Douglas including the 501/2 from Dumfries and
The nearest station is some 18-miles away in
The town is fairly compact and can be easily explored on foot; however a car or other means of transport is essential to explore the area around the town.

value: directions=To the west of the town

content=One of the National Trust for Scotland’s top ten most visited attractions, Threave Estate is the perfect place for a family day out – or two: there’s so much to see and do here, you may not fit it all in to one visit. Covering 647 hectares (1,600 acres), the estate is split into four main elements: Threave House, a restored Scottish baronial-style house; Threave Garden, made up of landscaped gardens and themed ‘rooms’; Threave Sculpture Garden, containing over 30 works by Scottish sculptors; and Threave Nature Reserve, featuring landscape ranging from wetlands to woodlands. Whichever part of the estate you’re in, you’ll see some of Threave’s famous wildlife – it’s one of Scotland’s bat hotspots, as well as a wildfowl sanctuary, and birds of all kinds flock here throughout the year.
directions=Off roundabout 0n A75 to west of town

content=On an island in the River Dee stands Threave Castle, a massive 14th century tower built by Archibald the Grim, Lord of Galloway. The stronghold of the Black Douglases, it has at its base an artillery fortification built before 1455 when James II besieged the castle Visitors have to travel to the island via a rowing boat. Also the location of the Osprey viewing platform
directions=At the south west side of the town
content=The town loch, feed the ducks, walk round or just enjoy. Caravan/Camp site available at the town end of the loch.

which lists events, attractions, seasonal events and other items of interest to both Tourists to the area and residents.

content=Pleasant seaside bay, plenty of rock pools to play in. At low tide you can walk across to Rough Island.
content=Watch the water sport enthusiasts or walk around the bay to Rockcliffe.

A small but lovely town for shopping with predominantly independent retailers including many food shops. King Street is the main shopping street.

value: content=The café is friendly, welcoming and comfortable. The only dog friendly café in Castle Douglas an ideal ‘refreshment stop’ during a walk.
directions=At eastern end of High Street set back in yard.
content=Castle Douglas' own brewery, where you can have a drink or buy off-sales to take home.
address=11-13 Main Street, Hough of Urr
directions=About 4-miles west of Castle Douglas signed off A75
content=A family-run pub with real ales and restaurant with excellent local food.
content=Traditional pub overlooking the old harbour, good food and accommodation also available. Real ales sold. If the weather is fair a great place to sit outside and watch the world go by.
address=206 King Street, Castle Douglas, DG7 1DB

content="The hotel has been tastefully modernised to meet the standards of today's traveller whilst retaining many of its original features.   The coaching credentials and the hotels reputation for hospitality have been well known over the years. The Douglas Arms Hotel is a warm and welcoming retreat for all."
directions=At the north end of Carlingshaw Loch.
content=108 caravan stances, 73 of which are on hard standing with a separate camping site for 53 tents.
